content.description: Big moves on excellent rock.  Super fun.
content.location: Start just right of Powerage and crank straight out the bulge.

content.description: Pull off the ground statically, traverse the sloping rail to its end, then make a big move for the lip.  Classic.
content.location: This boulder is located at the eastern end of a broad open area a few minutes past Skunk Cabbage Meadow, on the Willow Creek Trail. It's 100 yards uphill from the trail and faces southwest.

content.description: Thin crimps and poor feet through a smooth bulge. Move left as the landing drops away, and follow better holds to the top.
Great rock but too short to be a classic.  Sit start and climb perfect patina knobs just right of the tree.
content.location: Couple hundred yards southwest of the Deathless Millisecond.  Problem faces west.

content.description:
Climb interesting jugs to a long dyno near the top.

This climb is named after my ex-wife.  It's a little dirty but has a couple nice moves.
content.location: This is a south-facing boulder visible a short ways west of the trail, about a mile north of the Willow Creek/Cedar Laws junction, where the trail starts to steepen up to Hidden Divide.

content.description:
This is a great problem.  Start on good holds and climb an improbable sequence more or less straight up.  There's a tricky sequence midway and a thin move near the top.

This classic problem is named after my son.  Doden was one of his first verbalizations as a baby.

Variation (v0) - Move left around the arete and climb the slab above the tree.  Both have bad landings.
content.location: 100 yards east of the Willow Creek/Cedar Laws Trail junction.  The problem faces north.

content.description: A short fingertip crack through a steep panel of immaculate rock.
content.location: From Powerage, head west up the vague ridge, keeping to its left side, for ten minutes.  The problem faces west. It's 100 yards west of Amplitude and slightly uphill.

content.description:
Climb the center of the black wall past horizontals, aiming for nice patina edges up high.  There's a reachy move between good edges near the top.

Darth Croofer is a character my son invented when he was three years old.  He is a lesser-known relative of D. Vader.
content.location: The Willow Creek trail passes its namesake creek about 1 1/2 miles east of Saddle Junction. This problem is on a south-facing wall 50 yards up the creek.

content.description:
Fingertip and heel hook traverse along the steep right-angling crack. Either top out at the break in the middle, or go all the way right. Both finishes are great.

The righthand arete is also worthy. Stand start on a jug and pinch the overhanging arete till you can make a big move to the lip. Maybe v5 or so.
content.location: A mile east of Saddle Junction, as the trail begins to bend left toward Willow Creek. 50 yards SE of the trail and 100 yards SE of Powerage.  In the past this boulder was obscured by trees, but fire damage has made it visible from the trail.  Problem faces south.

content.description: This is a vertical face problem on beautiful caramel-colored rock.  The rock quality is primo.
content.location: 100 yards below Saddle Junction is an obvious 30' dihedral (5.7).  Caramello is hidden around the corner to the left.

content.description: A deceptively easy-looking problem on great rock.  Sit start on slopers and glide past enticing crack features to the top.
content.location: From Powerage, head west up the vague ridge, keeping to its left side, for 5-10 minutes.  The problem faces south.

climbs.name: Alien vs. Predator vs. Bouldering Gems

content.description: This eye-catching line begins with a bouldery sequence to get to the hanging groove up high. The groove looks easy but turns out to be delightfully insecure and terrifying. A classic.
content.location: 5 minutes past Willow Creek, 50 yards west of the trail. The problem faces east.
